Score the Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-I)

Source: R/score_pgii.R
score_pgii.Rd

Scores the PGI-I, a single-item measure assessing patient-reported improvement following treatment. The function includes robust input validation, detailed logging, and handles missing values according to scoring guidelines.

Usage

score_pgii(
  patient_data,
  item_name,
  id_column = "Record_ID",
  keep_n_valid = FALSE,
  verbose = FALSE,
  output_file = NULL
)

Arguments

patient_data

A data frame containing the PGI-I response variable.

item_name

The column name in the data frame that contains the PGI-I response. This must be a valid column in patient_data containing values 1-7 or NA.

id_column

Character string specifying the column name containing patient identifiers. Default is "Record_ID".

keep_n_valid

Logical, whether to return the number of valid, non-missing responses in the output. Default is FALSE.

verbose

Logical indicating whether to print detailed logging messages. Default is FALSE.

output_file

Character string specifying the path to save the results. If NULL (default), results are not saved to a file.

Value

A data frame containing:

  • pgii_score - The original PGI-I response score (1-7 or NA)

  • pgii_improved - A binary variable indicating if the patient reported improvement (scores between 1 and 3 are considered improvement, scores between 4 and 7 are considered no improvement/worsening)

  • pgii_n_valid - (Optional) The number of valid responses

Details

The PGI-I is a single-item global rating scale where patients rate their improvement after treatment on a scale from 1 (very much better) to 7 (very much worse). Lower scores indicate better perceived improvement.

PGI-I response scale:

  • 1: Very much better

  • 2: Much better

  • 3: A little better

  • 4: No change

  • 5: A little worse

  • 6: Much worse

  • 7: Very much worse

How Missing Data is Handled

If the PGI-I response is missing (NA), the function will return NA for the score and the binary improvement indicator.

References

Yalcin, I., & Bump, R. C. (2003). Validation of two global impression questionnaires for incontinence. American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology, 189(1), 98-101.

Examples

# Example 1: Basic usage with default parameters
patient_data <- data.frame(
  Record_ID = c("P001", "P002", "P003", "P004"),
  pgii_response = c(1, 3, 5, NA)
)

pgii_scores <- score_pgii(
  patient_data = patient_data,
  item_name = "pgii_response",
  id_column = "Record_ID",
  keep_n_valid = FALSE,
  verbose = TRUE
)
#> INFO [2025-03-28 01:20:11] Starting PGI-I score calculation
#> INFO [2025-03-28 01:20:11] Input parameters: item_name = %s, id_column = %s, keep_n_valid = %s, verbose = %s, output_file = %spgii_responseRecord_IDFALSETRUENULL
#> INFO [2025-03-28 01:20:11] Input validation successful
#> INFO [2025-03-28 01:20:11] Extracted data for %d patients4
#> INFO [2025-03-28 01:20:11] PGI-I scores calculated: %d valid, %d missing31
print(pgii_scores)
#> # A tibble: 4 × 3
#>   Record_ID pgii_score pgii_improved
#>   <chr>          <dbl>         <dbl>
#> 1 P001               1             1
#> 2 P002               3             1
#> 3 P003               5             0
#> 4 P004              NA            NA

# Example 2: With custom ID column and including count of valid responses
patient_data <- data.frame(
  PatientID = c("A", "B", "C", "D", "E"),
  Treatment = c("Drug", "Placebo", "Drug", "Drug", "Placebo"),
  GlobalImpression = c(2, 4, 1, 3, 6)
)

pgii_scores <- score_pgii(
  patient_data = patient_data,
  item_name = "GlobalImpression",
  id_column = "PatientID",
  keep_n_valid = TRUE,
  verbose = TRUE
)
#> INFO [2025-03-28 01:20:11] Starting PGI-I score calculation
#> INFO [2025-03-28 01:20:11] Input parameters: item_name = %s, id_column = %s, keep_n_valid = %s, verbose = %s, output_file = %sGlobalImpressionPatientIDTRUETRUENULL
#> INFO [2025-03-28 01:20:11] Input validation successful
#> INFO [2025-03-28 01:20:11] Extracted data for %d patients5
#> INFO [2025-03-28 01:20:11] PGI-I scores calculated: %d valid, %d missing50
print(pgii_scores)
#> # A tibble: 5 × 4
#>   PatientID pgii_score pgii_improved pgii_n_valid
#>   <chr>          <dbl>         <dbl>        <int>
#> 1 A                  2             1            5
#> 2 B                  4             0            5
#> 3 C                  1             1            5
#> 4 D                  3             1            5
#> 5 E                  6             0            5

# Example 3: Save results to file
patient_data <- data.frame(
  Record_ID = 1:5,
  pgii_response = c(2, 3, 4, 1, NA)
)

temp_file <- tempfile(fileext = ".csv")
pgii_scores <- score_pgii(
  patient_data = patient_data,
  item_name = "pgii_response",
  output_file = temp_file,
  verbose = TRUE
)
#> INFO [2025-03-28 01:20:11] Starting PGI-I score calculation
#> INFO [2025-03-28 01:20:11] Input parameters: item_name = %s, id_column = %s, keep_n_valid = %s, verbose = %s, output_file = %spgii_responseRecord_IDFALSETRUE/tmp/RtmpHm97TJ/file7690fd5a0c4.csv
#> INFO [2025-03-28 01:20:11] Input validation successful
#> INFO [2025-03-28 01:20:11] Extracted data for %d patients5
#> INFO [2025-03-28 01:20:11] PGI-I scores calculated: %d valid, %d missing41
#> INFO [2025-03-28 01:20:11] Saving results to file: %s/tmp/RtmpHm97TJ/file7690fd5a0c4.csv
# Results saved to temp_file
